definitions: move quickly to one side to avoid something coming towards you
avoid dealing with something difficult or unpleasant by using clever tactics
examples: He dodged the ball thrown at his head
The boxer dodged every punch with amazing skill
She always dodges questions about her personal life
Politicians often dodge difficult topics during interviews

definitions: engage in close combat between military aircraft in the air
fight or compete intensely with someone in a difficult situation
examples: The pilots engaged in a dangerous dogfight above the clouds
World War Two movies often show dramatic dogfights
The two companies dogfight for control of the market
The candidates will dogfight over every vote

definitions: put on an item of clothing or equipment
examples: She donned her winter coat before going outside
The workers must don safety helmets before entering

definitions: make simple drawings or patterns while thinking about something else
examples: Students often doodle in their notebooks during lectures
She doodled flowers on the margins while talking

definitions: make certain that something terrible will happen to someone or something
examples: The bad weather doomed our picnic plans completely
Poor planning doomed the project from the start

definitions: add drugs or chemicals to something, especially to affect performance
work out or understand something after thinking about it
examples: Someone doped the racehorse before the important race
Athletes who dope face lifetime bans from competition
Can you dope out what this message means
It took hours to dope out the solution

definitions: fit together precisely or harmoniously like interlocking parts
examples: Their schedules dovetail perfectly for the joint project
The new evidence dovetails with our earlier findings

definitions: reduce something to a lower grade, rank, or level of importance
examples: The storm was downgraded from hurricane to tropical storm
They downgraded his job title after the reorganization

definitions: make something appear less important or serious than it really is
examples: The company tried to downplay the environmental damage
Don't downplay your achievements in the job interview

definitions: make something smaller in size or scale than before
reduce the number of employees in a company to cut costs
examples: They decided to downsize their house after retirement
We need to downsize our luggage for the trip
The corporation plans to downsize by twenty percent
Many workers fear the company will downsize soon

definitions: search for underground water using a special rod or stick
pour water or another liquid over something to wet it
examples: The farmer hired someone to dowse for water sources
He claimed he could dowse for gold deposits
Dowse the flames with water to prevent spreading
She dowsed herself with cold water after running

definitions: force someone to do something they do not want to do
examples: They dragooned him into helping with the fundraiser
She was dragooned into organizing the office party

definitions: arrange cloth or clothing loosely over something in graceful folds
examples: She draped the scarf around her shoulders elegantly
They draped flags over the balcony for celebration

definitions: feel extreme fear or anxiety about something that will or might happen
examples: I dread going to the dentist every six months
She dreaded telling her parents about failing grades

definitions: clear the bottom of a river or harbor by scooping out mud
bring up something from the past that was forgotten or hidden
examples: They dredge the harbor every year for safety
Workers dredged tons of mud from the canal
Why dredge up painful memories from twenty years ago
Reporters dredged up scandals from his past

definitions: let liquid flow slowly in drops or a thin stream
move a ball forward by bouncing it continuously while running
examples: Water dribbled from the leaky faucet all night
The baby dribbled milk down her chin
He dribbled the basketball down the court expertly
Practice dribbling with both hands to improve skills

definitions: fall or let fall in small drops of liquid
examples: Water dripped from the umbrella onto the floor
The faucet drips constantly and needs fixing soon

definitions: rain in very fine drops that fall slowly and gently
pour a liquid in a thin stream over food
examples: It drizzled all morning but cleared by noon
The weather forecast says it will drizzle tomorrow
Drizzle olive oil over the salad before serving
The chef drizzled chocolate sauce on the dessert

definitions: make a continuous low humming or buzzing sound
speak in a boring way for a long time without stopping
examples: Bees droned lazily in the summer garden flowers
The airplane engine droned overhead for several minutes
The professor droned on about statistics for hours
He droned through his presentation without any enthusiasm

definitions: bend or hang downward limply through tiredness, weakness, or lack of support
examples: The flowers drooped in the intense summer heat
His shoulders drooped with exhaustion after the race

definitions: kick a ball by dropping it and kicking before it hits ground
examples: The rugby player dropkicked the ball between the posts
He scored three points with a perfect dropkick

definitions: do hard, boring, or unpleasant work for long periods of time
examples: She drudged in the kitchen all day preparing meals
Factory workers drudged through twelve hour shifts daily

definitions: give someone or something an unofficial name or title
replace the original soundtrack of a film with a different language
examples: They dubbed him the king of late night television
The media dubbed the scandal Watergate after the hotel
The movie was dubbed into Spanish for local audiences
They dubbed the foreign film with English voice actors

definitions: fight a formal combat between two people to settle a dispute
examples: In the past, gentlemen would duel to defend honor
The two politicians seemed ready to duel over policy

definitions: make something less sharp or able to cut effectively
make something less intense, interesting, or lively than before
examples: Cutting rope will dull your knife blade quickly
Years of use had dulled the scissors completely
The painkiller dulled the throbbing in her tooth
Routine work can dull your creative thinking abilities

definitions: dip food into a liquid quickly before eating it
score in basketball by jumping and forcing ball down through hoop
examples: Children love to dunk cookies in milk before eating
He dunked his donut in the hot coffee
The tall player dunked the ball with both hands
She can dunk despite being shorter than most players

definitions: deceive or trick someone into believing something that is not true
examples: The con artist duped elderly people out of savings
Don't let smooth talkers dupe you into bad deals

definitions: make an exact copy of something using the same materials or information
examples: Please duplicate these keys at the hardware store
Scientists struggled to duplicate the experimental results exactly

definitions: make something seem very small by comparison with something much larger
examples: The skyscrapers dwarf the old buildings around them
His achievements dwarf those of his famous father

definitions: live in a particular place as a resident
think, speak, or write at length about a particular subject
examples: Native tribes dwelled in these mountains for centuries
Many artists dwell in this creative neighborhood community
Don't dwell on past mistakes that cannot be changed
She tends to dwell on negative thoughts too much

definitions: gradually become smaller in size, amount, or strength over time
examples: Our savings dwindled after months without steady income
The crowd dwindled as the rain became heavier

definitions: change the color of something using a special liquid substance
examples: She decided to dye her hair bright red
They dye the fabric using natural plant extracts

definitions: blow up or destroy something using the explosive substance dynamite
examples: Workers dynamited the old bridge to build new one
Miners dynamite rock formations to extract valuable minerals

definitions: flow back out to sea as the tide goes out
gradually decrease in strength, importance, or quantity over time
examples: The tide ebbs twice daily in coastal areas
Watch the water ebb away from the shoreline
His enthusiasm began to ebb after many rejections
Support for the proposal ebbed as problems emerged

definitions: block light from one celestial body by another passing between
be much more successful or important than someone or something
examples: The moon will eclipse the sun next Tuesday afternoon
Clouds eclipsed the stars on the cloudy night
Her achievements eclipse those of previous record holders
The scandal eclipsed all other news that week

definitions: move in a circular motion like water or air forming small whirlpools
examples: Leaves eddied in the wind around the courtyard
Water eddied behind the rocks in the stream

definitions: force someone or something out of a place suddenly and with force
examples: The pilot ejected from the damaged fighter plane safely
Security guards ejected the troublemakers from the concert

definitions: develop or present something in further detail with more information
examples: Could you elaborate on your proposal for us
She refused to elaborate about her future plans

definitions: supply electrical power to something or convert it to use electricity
cause someone to feel sudden excitement or thrilling emotion
examples: They plan to electrify the rural railway system soon
The village was electrified only ten years ago
Her powerful speech electrified the entire audience instantly
The announcement electrified investors around the world

definitions: raise something to a higher position or level physically or in importance
examples: The nurse elevated his injured leg with extra pillows
The promotion elevated her to senior management level

definitions: draw out a response, answer, or fact from someone often with difficulty
examples: The teacher tried to elicit answers from shy students
Her jokes failed to elicit even a small smile

definitions: make something longer in shape or duration than it was before
examples: The artist elongated the figure to create dramatic effect
Stretching exercises help elongate tight muscles before running

definitions: run away secretly with someone to get married without parental approval
examples: The young couple eloped to Las Vegas last weekend
They decided to elope rather than plan expensive wedding

definitions: make something clear by explaining it in more detail
examples: The professor elucidated complex theories with simple examples
Please elucidate your position on this important matter

definitions: escape from or avoid someone or something by being quick or skillful
examples: The criminal eluded police for three months before capture
Success continues to elude him despite working very hard

definitions: come out from a source and spread through the surrounding area
examples: A strange smell emanated from the old basement room
Confidence emanated from her as she entered confidently

definitions: officially ban trade or commercial activity with a particular country
examples: The government decided to embargo all imports from there
Several nations embargo goods from countries violating human rights

definitions: begin a journey, especially on a ship, or start something new
examples: Passengers embark at the main terminal before noon daily
She embarked on a new career in her forties

definitions: cause someone to feel ashamed, awkward, or uncomfortable in social situations
examples: Please don't embarrass me in front of my friends
His loud behavior embarrassed his teenage daughter greatly

definitions: fix an object firmly and deeply in a surrounding mass or substance
examples: The arrow embedded itself deep in the tree trunk
Journalists were embedded with military units during war
